clinical_study.brief_title: Effectiveness Study of Short Course of Magnesium Sulfate for Severe Preeclamsia
clinical_study.official_title: Postpartum Prophylaxis With Short Course Magnesium Sulfate in Severe Preeclampsia: a Randomized Clinical Trial

lead_sponsor.agency: Instituto Materno Infantil Prof. Fernando Figueira

clinical_study.source: Instituto Materno Infantil Prof. Fernando Figueira

brief_summary.textblock: Magnesium sulfate is the ideal drug for seizures prophilaxis in preeclampsia. The ideal duration of this treatment after delivery is still to be established. The hypothesis is that in stable patients a shorter course of treatment is possible without prejudice to the mother.

detailed_description.textblock: Magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) is certainly the ideal drug for prevention and control of eclamptic seizures. However, there is no consensus on the appropriate duration of prophylaxis with this anticonvulsant postpartum.The objective of the present study is to compare effectiveness of 12 hours of magnesium sulfate versus 24 hours (standard treatment) in stable patients with preeclampsia.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Need to continue therapy for another 12 hours.
primary_outcome.description: Defined as the need to continue therapy for another 12 hours, this will occur when after the first 12 hours of magnesium sulfate therapy the patient has severe hypertension, unsatisfactory diureses or has signs or symptoms of iminent eclampsia.

secondary_outcome.description: Patients satisfaction with the duration of therapy

arm_group.description: Patients in this group will have magnesium sulfate administered for 12 hours after delivery
Patients in this group will have magnesium sulfate administered for 24 hours after delivery
